Qst.Quest: the number, description and identity of contracts, consultancies or disbursements entered into, awarded or approved by his Department since coming into office; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: The number of contracts awarded, or approved, by my Department since July 1997 would run to thousands and it would take an inordinate level of resources to compile details of each of them. However, it has been a long-standing practice for my Department to adhere to EU and Government contracts committee procedures in award of contracts. Furthermore, my Department's tender and contract procedures are subject to audit by internal auditors, the Comptroller and Auditor General, and EU auditors.
The information on consultancies is being compiled at present and will be forwarded to the Deputy as quickly as possible.
If the Deputy has a concern about the procedures used in any contract, or consultancy, awarded or approved by my Department, I will have the case examined.

Qst.Quest: if he will respond to the concerns of those involved in the Blanchardstown, Dublin 15 area in relation to much needed accommodation for the promotion of adult literacy in line with Green Paper deliberations (details supplied).

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: My Department has already written to the Office of Public Works on this matter. The Department has sought that the premises in question be used for early school leaver, adult literacy and community education programmes later this year, when the premises at Blanchardstown Institute of Technology is operational and in a position to accommodate staff.

Qst.Quest: if teachers employed by vocational education committees are obliged to retire at 65 years of age if they are funding their own pensions and are not eligible for a pension from his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: The compulsory retirement age for teachers is 65.
Serving teachers may continue in their posts up to the end of the school year in which they reach 65 years of age.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Brady Mr. J. Brady
Qst.Quest: his Department's proposals for the appointment of a resource teacher at Convent of Mercy primary school, Kells, County Meath, in view of the urgent need for such a provision at the school to assist teachers to provide for the needs of the students; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: My Department's inspectorate is currently investigating the special educational needs of pupils attending the Convent of Mercy Primary School in Kells.
The outcome of this investigation will be available shortly and will provide a basis for determining the nature and level of additional support required by the pupils in question.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the way in which he can justify the disqualification of Irish people who enter higher education from State support if they have been out of the country for the previous three years in view of the right of Irish citizens to free movement; and the way in which this co-exists with the stated Government policy of supporting the return of those who have emigrated.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Under the free fees initiative, tuition fees are payable in respect of eligible EU nationals who have been ordinarily resident in an EU member state for at least three of the five years preceding entry to their third-level course. I would point out to the Deputy that this condition applies equally to all EU nationals, including Irish nationals, in accordance with the judgment of the European Court of Justice that access to vocational training must apply equally to all EU nationals. I understand that similar residency requirements operate in the other EU member states.
The removal of this residency condition for Irish nationals would have to apply to EU nationals generally and could have significant resource implications for the Exchequer.

I would further point out to the Deputy, the EU nationals who have been ordinarily resident in the administrative area of a local authority from 1 October of the year prior to going to college may apply for assistance under the higher education grants scheme. In this regard, EU nationals who do not satisfy the residency requirement under the free fees initiative may apply to have their fees paid if they satisfy the residency requirement (of one year in an EU member state) and the means test under the scheme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Children and Family Policy.

Qst.Quest: the areas of responsibility, if any, his Department has with regard to the Government's policy on children; the areas of responsibility, if any, his Department has with regard to the Government's policy on the family; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: While not having the lead role in addresing the specific issues mentioned in the Government's Programme under the two headings to which the Deputy refers, my Department has an essential contribution to make in these areas.

It is the responsibility of my Department to ensure that there is available to each person, including every person with a disability or other special need, a level and quality of education appropriate to the needs and abilities of that person.

In discharging its responsibility through the delivery of education services from pre-school to adult education, my Department ensures that developments in the child protection and care areas identified in the Government's Programme are fully taken on board.

In addition, my Department is engaged in implementing the range of specific measures relating to educational provision which have been set down in the Government's Programme. The measures in question include recognition of the important role of parents in the education of their children.
Following the National Forum for Early Childhood Education held last March, I announced the preparation of a White Paper which will set out Government policy in this regard.

As far as the family specifically is concerned, my Department was represented on the Commission for the Family, under the auspices of the Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs. The Commission reported last year, and its report focussed on a number of aspects of education, including early education and socio-economic disadvantage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - School Transport.

Qst.Quest: if he will allow children from the Aglish area of County Waterford to avail of transport to post primary schools in Youghal in view fo the fact that there are 13 children travelling three miles to and from the boundary of the catchment area to get transport to Youghal and this figure is likely to increase in the new school year; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: Eligible second level pupils who wish to attend a school outside of their own catchment area may be allowed transport only from within the catchment boundary of the school they attend, provided there are spare seats available and no extra State cost is involved.

MainHeading.P: The pupils from Aglish are in the Cappoquin catchment area but have opted to attend school in Youghal. Under the terms of the scheme, therefore, I regret that they can only be allowed transport from within the Youghal catchment area, subject to the conditions outlined above.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Reynolds Mr. G. Reynolds
Qst.Quest: when St. Michael's College, Ailesbury Road, Dublin 4, will be included in the schools IT 2000 programme.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: All primary schools recognised by my Department are included in the Schools IT 2000 initiative.
Since the primary school attached to St. Michael's College, Ailesbury Road, Dublin 4, is a private school, it is not included, therefore, in the Schools IT 2000 initiative.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Schools Building Projects.

Qst.Quest: if his recent announcement regarding funding for primary school buildings will affect positively the proposal for a new school at Drumphea, County Carlow; when this school will be provided; and the current position in this regard.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: On 10 January, I announced a new initiative on State ownership of schools at primary and post-primary levels.

MainHeading.P: In my statement of 10 January, I indicated that discussions would be held with all interested parties on the operational arrangements for the new initiative. To this end, a working group has been established in my Department and is currently examining the implementation details. When this work has been finalised, I will confirm the position in relation to individual schools, such as Drumphea.

In the meantime, architectural planning for the new building is under way. The project is at the early stages of the planning process. At this stage, it is not feasible for me to give a commencement date for construction. I can assure the Deputy that every effort will be made to expedite the project.

Qst.Quest: if a person (details supplied) in County Mayo who is a trained montessori teacher is eligible for a permanent position in mainstream schools.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin):
Speaker.P: The person referred to by the Deputy completed the three year full time course in the Association Montessori Internationale (AMI) College, Mount St. Mary's, Milltown, Dublin 14 (formerly Sion Hill). Such teachers are recognised by my Department as qualified to teach only in special schools for the mentally handicapped, the emotionally disturbed, and the hearing impaired.
In addition, I have recently decided that AMI Montessori teachers will now be recognised as fully qualified for substitute teaching purposes in mainstream primary schools.
However, the person referred to by the Deputy is not eligible for a permanent position in mainstream national schools.
